captions.text:
JAMAL SIMS: Hey everybody,
I'm Jamal Sims.

DONDRAICO JOHNSON: And I'm
Dondraico Johnson.

JAMAL SIMS: And we are the
official choreographers on the

We're here today to teach the
Footloose line dance "Fake

ID." We've been getting so
many hits on Twitter and

people emailing about how
to do this dance.

So we thought it would be kind
of cool to come in and show

I'm going to teach you the first
two counts of eight of

All right, so we're going to
start here with our hands in

We go right foot, one, two
and three and four.

Five, brush six and
seven and eight.

From here, this is
our second eight.
The butt scoops to the back.

We step two and three,
together four.

We have our first two
eight counts.

We go one, two and
three, four.

Step five, brush six and
seven, scoop eight.

Now brush around one, two and
three, together four.

So we're just going to
put it together.
Five, six and seven and eight.

JAMAL SIMS: And one, two
and three, four.

DONDRAICO JOHNSON: So now we're
going to move on to the

You can open up your
feet-- one and two.

Hop with your left foot
out and tap it back--

When you turn, you hop
on your right--

Hop on your left--
five and six.

That's the top of the
third eight count.

Let's move on to the
fourth eight count.

You're going to step
with your left.

One, turn two, step
three and four.

Go step five, hit six,
seven, eight.

And you make sure you
slap your little--

For the guys, we're going
to slap our legs.

JAMAL SIMS: Let's do all four
eight counts together.
Five, six and seven and eight.

Swoop one, two and
three, four.

Open one and two, hop
three and four.
Step one, two, three and four.

This is our last two
counts of eight.

We go one, two and three,
click four.

For ladies, the lower you
can go, the better.

The guys just stay up and
keep it really cool.

So we just did seven
and eight.

We're going to rock
our hips around--
Right foot goes in the back.

And five and six and
seven and eight.

So we go five, six,
seven, eight.

We go one, two and three,
click four.

And five and six and
seven, eight.

On the last count of eight,
we're going to have you turn

around to the original position
on four counts.

It goes one and two and
three and four.

And you're going to loop this
dance from the beginning all

And that will continue
on through the song.

All the way through,
from the top.

JAMAL SIMS: Five, six,
seven, eight.

JAMAL SIMS: Bah, bah, bah,
bah, bah, bah, bah, bah.

That's the "Fake ID" line
dance from Footloose.

DONDRAICO JOHNSON: Yes,
we can't wait to

title: Footloose 2011 - Official Dance Tutorial - Fake ID Line Dance

comments.text:
I am going to do this at my sisters wedding. She is having a country themed 
wedding and I want the bridal party to surprise her with this line dance. I 
have been trying to learn it myself it only took me about a half an hour to 
learn the steps but once I try to speed up to go with the music I get all 
flustered and can't seem to get it. Any tips?﻿
comments.author: CountryChickee

comments.text:
Same here, I know all the steps but once I try to do it to the music, I get 
all messed up. I guess practice makes perfect, once you've got a nice 
rhythm going, try speeding it up slightly every time and then you'll 
eventually get up to speed :)
comments.author: Robin Lynch

comments.text:
I have danced for a while, and thia is hard to learn. My biggest crtitique 
for this video is keeping the camera angles the same when showing the steps 
because when it switches and I personally am trying to follow along it 
slows be down quite a bit﻿

comments.text: hello﻿
comments.author: Lorena Infante

comments.text:
I am 14 years old. My friend, Lupita is doing this dance for the surprise 
dance at her quinceañera... We've been learning this dance for the past 5 
weeks for two hours a day/ 3 times a week... We just got this down last 
week and when we do it fast, with the song, I keep messing up and I get 
called out for it at practice.. Sometimes I can Get it and other times, I 
can't seem to dance it.... And I was the first one out of the ten that were 
there to get the dance down without the music... Does anyone have any tips 
for me for getting it down with the music?? Please help.. ﻿
comments.author: Shannon Berreth

comments.text:
I hope its not too late to help you out... I've been in musicals and such 
all throughout junior high/high school and a few in college. If I ever had 
a dance I was struggling with, I always took it very slow until I got it 
down and THEN gradually sped it back up. This trick works with almost 
everything. If you need music to help you, slow the music down. Also, I've 
never taken the time to do this but I've heard recording yourself and 
watching the recordings works. It helps you visually see what you're not 
getting. I hope this helps!
comments.author: Robert Lafferty

comments.text: Country swag.﻿
comments.author: Mackenzie Rutherford

comments.text:
Anybody got any help or tips for me... my fiancé loves to dance and 
currently we are forced separated (I'm Active Duty Air Force on base in 
another state) and I I enjoy it too, but I am having a hard time learning 
all the footsteps but really want to surprise her for her 21st birthday 
coming up the end of September. Any help or tips would be awesome! ﻿
comments.author: Jordan Meek

comments.text:
This line dance isn't for beginners, I've been line dancing basically my 
whole life and this dance gets me. Just keep practicing, try a slower song 
than FAKE ID to get use to the steps. When Stoney's in Las Vegas teaches a 
new line dance or any line dance they start us off with a slower song first 
and then next time around pump up the speed of the song for a more 
difficult dance. It took me a few tries to get Chill Factor but after I got 
it I love it and it is my FAVORITE dance. If you are new to line dancing 
try a few easier line dances to get use to it. ﻿
comments.author: Corinna Thompson

comments.text:
I am hip hop dancer from 10 years but it is very hard for me to learn this 
dance,so RESPECT for country dancers!﻿
comments.author: Teddy Deinaviey

comments.text:
Wonderful instruction gentlemen.  May I say that your pants coming off 
takes my attention off the dance and onto the possibility of you loosing 
them.  No offense but there is nothing masculine about diaper drooping 
pants. I just don't get it. If it's fashion then someone needs to change 
it. It wouldn't be cute to me being on a date with someone and their pants 
falling off. I wouldn't have gone on a date with a person who looked like 
that in the first place. I really don't mean to be mean but do you think 
this is professional looking?  You're having to reach down all the time to 
keep your pants up. It's just so silly to see a grown man do this. How do 
you explain this fashion to children? "I want sex so I wear pants that slip 
down so my underwear can be seen. Women really go for that." Try explaining 
that to your children some day. A player that lets his pants fall off is 
about as smart as cutting the zipper off your pants and letting your boxers 
been seen. PLUS you could cut holes in your shirt where your nipples are. 
Makes about as much sense.﻿
comments.author: Songs Mirth

comments.text:
um, I'm not trying to start something but he's wearing sweat pants because 
they are easier to move around in and are more comfortable when dancing. 
He's jumping, twisting, lifting his legs and turning his hips, of course 
his pants are going to sag down. At least he kept pulling them up 
throughout the video. It wasn't about trying to be or not to be masculine, 
but rather just a reaction to his body moving. Please try to understand the 
situation before judging someone, who they are and how they act in their 
every day lives.

comments.author: DancinQueen Sabi

comments.text:
This is fast because it's not meant to be a beginners line dance. If you 
want to get it, you're going to have to keep pausing and going over the 
steps piece by piece until you get it. Stop it after this first 8 count and 
perfect it then continue on with the second eight count and so on. Don't do 
it in sections like they're doing unless you follow choreography well.﻿

comments.author: Hailey Gillenwater

comments.text:
Practice each set of 8 counts till you get them right, dont worry about 
putting them together just yet. Then once you get the muscle memory going 
on the steps then you can start combining them. This is a rather long and 
complex dance, dont get too discouraged about not picking it up right away.
